organizations: Fox Sports Caroline Zielinski News Corp Australia Network Share Email
title: Extreme stunts gone horribly wrong
text:
Confessions of a flight attendant 13:42 PM SARAH STEEGAR, FLIGHT ATTENDANT WHEN they start, new cabin crew members have no idea what they’re in for. Sarah Steegar knows that all too well. Extreme stunts gone horribly wrong 11:57 AM Caroline Zielinski JUMPING off a cliff or walking a tightrope between two buildings seems like a great idea to impress your mates, but it’s rare that these stunts go to plan. WARNING: Don’t try this at home. Plane passenger’s Bridesmaids moment 11:26 AM Ian Horswill IT began when a young woman on a flight to Chicago kicked the seat of a passenger in front. Then she kissed an attendant and punched her — and it got worse. Creepy photo shows what lies beneath us 11:12 AM JERRY HARMER HIDDEN underneath this popular location lies a fascinating underworld of abandoned paths that have sunk. They’re straight out of your nightmares. Pitt’s pitch for a new-look Queensland 9:23 AM Jason Tin LOOK at any tourist hotspot in Queensland and you’ll find a bunch of tired resorts. But Treasurer Curtis Pitt has a plan to turn them around — and boost tourism in the state at the same time. Daredevil nearly drowns in botched stunt 7:38 AM Sophia Rosenbaum and Staff Writers DRAMATIC video shows the moment an escape artist is trapped in a locked box filled with water and nearly drowns in front of a live audience. ‘White object’ spotted off Reunion 5:52 AM AFP and Network Writers AN AIR France pilot has reported seeing a ‘white object’ floating near Reunion Island where a wing part from MH370 was found two months ago. These stuns may seem like a fun idea, but their consequences are very real — and very dangerous September 16, 2015 11:57am Not the best idea ... A stuntman is consumed by flames as he desperately holds on to the car driving through flames. Picture: Fox Sports Caroline Zielinski News Corp Australia Network Share Email a friend 
WHILE extreme stunts are fascinating — both to watch and try — they are more often than not dangerous. 
We have complied a list of five stunts that seemed like a good idea, but that, in the end, just went horribly wrong. 
1. Dean Potter’s extreme jump 
Extreme American climber and base jumper Dean Potter, 43, known for stunts such as walking barefoot on a rope connected between two mountain peaks in Enshi, Hubei province in China, took it a step too far earlier this year when he and fellow extreme athlete Graham Hunt, 29, decided to jump off a cliff in Yosemite National Park. 
Despite wearing wingsuits designed to help them fly clear of an outcrop on the cliff face, the pair failed to get past it, and tragically plunged to their death jumping from a spot 915 metres above the valley floor. 
In 2008, Potter told The New York Times that while a part of him thought it was crazy for a person to attempt to fly, “another part of me thinks all of us had the dream that we can fly. Why not chase after it?” 
2. The “Death Swing” at Hanging Rock 
Only a week ago, Aussie daredevil Toby Benham, 32, known as Lucky Chance, fatally smashed into jagged rocks at Hanging Rock, Blackheath, while trying to complete a Blue Mountains clifftop stunt known as the “Death Swing”. Hanging Rock, Blackheath ... Scene where Toby Benham, aka Lucky Chance, died. Picture: Supplied Source: The Daily Telegraph 
A former Lennon Brothers Circus performer, he spent weeks recovering in a French hospital from another cliff jump gone wrong about four years ag, where broke his pelvis, his lung collapsed and he was in a coma. 
This time, however, he wasn’t as lucky. 
Hanging Rock, where Lucky Chance died, is a popular location for rope swinging. Toby Benham also known as "Lucky Chance" who was killed after swinging from a rope attached to Hanging Rock in the Blue Mountains. Pictured at Yosemite National Park in California, United States Source: Facebook 
3. Near-drown 
Escape artist Spencer Horsman’s public performance at the State Theatre last night went seriously wrong after he got into massive trouble while performing his “Water Torture Cell” stunt, which includes Horsman submerging himself, wrapped in metal chains, in a see-through glass and metal box filled with water. 
He and the box are hoisted into the air as he is supposed to be freeing himself. Near death ... Magician and escape artist Spencer Horsman attempts a death-defying water escape in front of the State Theatre in New Brunswick. Picture: Alex Remnick/NJ.com Source: Supplied 
However, the box had to be quickly lowered as Horsman struggled inside the water. Four men then rushed over to unlock the box and quickly dragged his limp body out. He was rushed to the hospital soon after. Escape artist Spencer Horsman nearly drowns in stunt gone wrong in New Brunswick More @CBSNewYork pic.twitter.com/KO52YxszVT — Meg Baker (@megbakertv) September 15, 2015 
4. Driving through fire 
When one daredevil thought it’d be clever to lie down on the outside of a jeep and have someone drive it through a burning wall, he probably thought, what could go wrong? Aflame ... The stuntman desperately holds on as the car drives through the burning circle. Picture: Fox Sports Source: Supplied 
Plenty, it transpired. After crashing through the burning wall, the stuntman is lit on fire, panics, lets go of the car, falls down on the ground and is run over by the car. 
Curiously, the stuntman appears unharmed and just walks off afterwards. Hmmm. Under the wheels ... The daredevil is shown being run over the car after the stunt goes horribly wrong. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied 
And here’s the full video, curtesy of Fox Sports : 
5. The drunk trampoline bounce 
Considering that most daredevil stunts are by their very nature extremely dangerous, going into them drunk adds just another layer of insanity. 
So when UK prankster Jordan Adlard, 26, decided to jump off a very high tree and onto a trampoline at a party while drunk, it’s a mirage he even survived. 
Self-dubbed as the “human cannonball”, Adlard was at his cousin’s party when he decided to leap onto a trampoline from a 6-metre tree. 
While not clear what he expected to happen, the result was pretty tragic: he bounced off and smashed into a wooden fence, breaking his back. 
But wait for the kicker: he didn't actually find that out until eight days later, after he went to the hospital following a breakdancing episode which finally revealed the pain. 
According to The Mirror , doctors told Adlard that he had in fact suffered a compression fracture in his spine, which would have almost certainly become permanently damaged had he waited much longer.
